awd_titl_txt: CSBR Ownership Transfer: Saving an ecologically data-rich collection: adding the Geological Survey of Alabama Fish Collection to The University of Alabama Ichthyological Collection
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of Alabama - Tuscaloosa to acquire the fish collection of the Geological Survey of Alabama (GSA).  This collection of over 450,000 specimens of freshwater fishes from throughout the State, provides an unparalleled record of the occurrence, distribution, and ecology of these species in the Tennessee and Mobile River basins, will be transferred to the University of Alabama Ichthyological Collection (UAIC).  The transfer will secure the collection at UAIC and ensure the long-term care of these valuable specimens, as well as providing increased access to the specimens and associated ecological data through the UAIC web portal (specifyweb.as.ua.edu) and those of project partners (GBIF, FishNet2, VertNet, and iDigBio).  The intensive sampling effort that resulted in the GSA collection makes it of particular importance to the research community including its use in student training and research. 

This project transfers ownership of the GSA fish collection into UAIC, providing immediate curatorial intervention to a very large collection of freshwater fishes and associated ecological data that would otherwise be lost to the scientific community.  Addition of these specimens into UAIC augments and supplements the material currently in UAIC in both the number of specimens and the value of the associated collection and ecological data to the research community.  The GSA collection represents intensive sampling throughout Alabama and surrounding drainages and potentially informs systematics, biogeography, taxonomy, life-history, and ecological studies.  The environmental data associated with a large portion of the specimens provide time-series information usable by conservation biologists, ecologists and land managers to document human impacts and environmental changes across freshwater aquatic ecosystems in Alabama.  The GSA collection also greatly increases UAIC's holdings of threatened and endangered species endemic to Alabama, and facilitates future research on these taxa by providing electronic access to these valuable specimens.  By uniting these collections and providing access to associated field data through several biodiversity information portals an invaluable resource documenting freshwater fish biodiversity in Alabama and the southeastern United States is made available for training and research.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Natural history collections form a foundation of our understanding of life sciences on earth. In this project we rescued an extremely valuable collection of preserved freshwater fishes from the most diverse region for these species in all of North America. The Geological Survey of Alabama (GSA) began collecting fish samples in the late 1970s as part of their Ecosystems Investigations Division. During their 30+ year effort, they collected >408,000 fish specimens from every named tributary in Alabama, a remarkable feat and an invaluable resource for scientists interested in freshwater biodiversity and wildlife management.

Despite the value of these speciemens, many were stored in inadequate conditions and very little of the material was cataloged in an electronic format so that scientists could use specimen data in research. We integrated all of these specimens into the University of Alabama Ichthological Collection (UAIC) making certain that all specimens were stored in high-quality jars, with appropriate preservatives, in a climate controlled facility.  This integration included archiving all specimen data into our collection database making these data easily accessible in a format that scientists can use. We then quality checked these data and sent them our partners at large biodiversity data agregattors such as VertNet, GBIF, and iDigBio. Now all of these data are searchable by both researchers and the general public via their websites.

Beyond the more obvious outcomes such as specimen security, the integration of the GSA material has also inspired and improved research projects. While working on the integration, one of our students discovered several specimens of a fish species that were from a location outside their native range. Upon revisiting this site, the student found a stable population of this species and two additional species outside their known range leading her to an interesting research topic for her masters thesis and a publication in a peer-reviewed journal. She continues to work on manuscripts associated with this project into her PhD program.

Another utility of the GSA collection is using the biodiversity and collection data (e.g., taxa, date, location, habitat, collection method) to perform meta-analyses. The UAIC has become involved in several projects that use these types of data to examine historical trends in biodiversity and abundance of fishes related to land-use and climate change. For example, we joined a team of scientists based out of the University of Tennessee examining the history of invasive and non-native species present in the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers and how a warming climate might provide greater opportunity for invasions.

A third important outcome of this project is related the usefulness of these data to wildlife managers. The GSA conducted surveys and collected specimens for many species of conservation concern including the Cahaba Shiner, Blue Shiner, Goldline darter, Vermillion darter, and many others. Therefore, when wildlife managers are considering these and other species of concern for listing at the state or federal level, they rely on museum collection data to inform their management decisions. In 2021, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service began a species status assesment of the Coal darter which is endemic to the Cahaba River and Locust Fork of the Black Warrior River. With the addition of GSA material, the UAIC now contains the densest collection of this species and was vital to the preparation of this status assessment.

The final outcome of the project, which is often overlooked, is that more than two dozen college students worked on this project. Curatorial practices in natural history collections are not commonly taught in undergraduate and even graduate settings. However, the bulk of the work in this project was carried out by undergraduate and graduate students who now have experience working with natural history collections but also an understnading of their importance to society and the study of biology in general. Although not all of these students plan to seek carries in organismal biology, several have moved on to graduate programs investigating questions realted to environmental science, ecology, and evolutionary biology.  Thus, this project fostered appreciation of natural history collections and training in curatorial practices for students.

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2022
Modified by: Phillip M Harris
